summary: retrospective observational study at a single, university-affiliated center was performed to evaluate the respiratory viral infection etiologies in children compared to that in adults. the common viruses detected from children were human rhinovirus (hRV) (31.8%), adenovirus (AdV) (19.2%), respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) A (17.4%), RSV B (11.7%), and human metapneumovirus (9.8%). acute IFA, IFB, RSV A, RSV B, and hMPV showed strong seasonal patterns. the common comorbidities were diabetes mellitus, chronic renal disease, and malignancy. but nasal congestion and rhinorrhea were more common with hRV (82.8%) and hCoV-OC43 (69.2%) infection. lower respiratory infection was found in about 50% of patients for most viruses. solitary pathogens were more likely to be identified as solitary pathogens. hRV, EV, and hMPV were more likely to be identified as co-infections. the number of total co-detections was too low in adults. a microbiologic database was reviewed to identify the prevalence of 15 viruses in the hospitalized children and adults with acute respiratory infection. compared to the respiratory virus isolation rate in adults, the isolation rate was low in adults. hRV had the highest isolation rate, followed by AdV, RSV A/B, and hMPV, in children. differences likely originated from distinct study designs and patient populations. hRV and IFA/IFB were major pathogens associated with hospitalization. the number of cases was too small to compare the clinical outcomes. the occurrence of staphylococcal and pneumococcal pneumonia complicating Spanish influenza pandemics is well known. clinical diagnosis based on patient's age and clinical features should be made with discretion. real-time PCR assays should be considered in severe and complicated patients. etiology of respiratory viral infection appears to differ according to the patient's age.
